"Argo-f*ckyaself!" exclaim Tony Mendez (Ben Affleck), John Chambers (John Goodman), and Lester Siegel (Alan Arkin) the moment they realize their comically absurd idea to rescue 6 members of the U.S. Embassy in Tehran from angered Islamic militants during the 1979 Iranian Revolution actually gains some fruitful traction. Now that's something you can see Ben Affleck directing right? If you haven't seen his films Gone Baby Gone (2007) or The Town (2010), or even knew that he actually has directed, you may be answering with a marginal "Yes" to a flat out "No" to that question. Let's be honest, we all knew Affleck first as an actor, mostly for his great performance in Good Will Hunting (1997) and then...pretty much nothing else. He went down a pretty steep decline from there on with a slew of so-so action films, romedies/comedies, and dramas that, in the course of a decade, earned him 9 Golden Raspberry awards, scathing disapproval from comic nerds for Daredevil (2003) (now your memory is kicking in isn't it), and a declined interest from audiences. Personally, I always liked Affleck, and I actually didn't mind him as Daredevil (it really was just horrible, horrible direction), but I can't deny that the movies he has acted in are of poor substance. Then came his directing career, and I finally felt a rush of hope again for his stamp on Hollywood. His first two films I mentioned above are fantastic and are already a part of my movie collection; they proved that he had the capability of telling stories that were grounded in reality and that capitalized on the story itself and not on big action or insanely intricate set pieces to move it forward. With that being said, class is dismissed for Ben Affleck 101, and it's time to delve into his next great work- Argo.

Argo is a gripping, smart, and well-crafted suspense film that Affleck directs with such admirable attention that it's easily his most accomplished work; what it lacks in emotional substance it makes up for in its humor, acute pacing and structural balance, and entertaining political satire. The film is based on the true events from a former classified CIA operation that took place during the 1979 Iranian Revolution in Iran. During a ferocious mob protest just outside the gated U.S. Embassy of Tehran, Islamic activists, angry with the U.S. for supporting the ejection of their beloved Reza Shah, take over the embassy and all its staff except for six who are able to escape,  and are taken in by the Canadian ambassador in Iran Ken Taylor (Victor Garber). Surely to be captured and killed if found, these six Americans must stay indoors and out of sight until they can some how escape the country. Enter the United States State Department and CIA. Ex-fil and CIA specialist Tony Mendez is brought in, initially for consultation, to put together a plan to exfiltrate, or bring home, these trapped people. With the situation escalating quickly as the Islamic revolutionaries come closer to finding out that there are missing employees as well as the rise of Iranian security around every corner, all initial proposals to extract the employees prove to be ultimately ineffective. That is until Mendez lands on the idea that the best way to get their people back is to make a completely fabricated Hollywood, science-fiction film (along the lines of Star Wars) that requires "exotic" locations to shoot, that way he can enter Iran with less suspicion as well as disguise the six U.S. Embassy workers as a part of the film crew and convince the security at the Iran airport that they had been there for location scouting. With the help of two hilarious Hollywood "somebodies," make-up artist John Chambers and producer Lester Siegel, Mendez initiates his plan to fool not just one, but three countries (United States, Canada, Iran), into thinking a science-fiction movie by the name of Argo is actually in production in order to ensure diplomatic peace . Badda bing, badda boom, you got yourself a rescue mission of insanely improbable odds that makes for some heart-pounding and intense cinema.

If there's one thing this film nailed perfectly, it's tension. Affleck is able to expertly craft rising tension in both the opening sequence as well as the final act. Some of you are probably "edge of the seat" standers, but I'm a nail biting kinda guy, and my nails haven't been grossly pedicured by my teeth due to a film in a while, until now. These scenes are truly enchanting, and the key to creating such palpable suspense is by utilizing simple "cause and effect" scenarios that hook to large and catastrophic consequences, consequences that are slowly established through the course of the film; this Affleck accomplishes with a natural feel.

You wouldn't think at first, but this film actually has a large, sort of ensemble, cast. They aren't exactly A-list celebs, but the supporting roles are filled with familiar and respectable actors who you are surely to recognize from television and other film. Shout out to Titus Weliver who played The Man in Black on Lost who makes an appearance here! Love him! The performances all around are solid, no one drags but no one rises above the bar. The best performances I'm going to give to John Goodman, who has never been so good, as well as Alan Arkin, who provide the film with most of its humor as the comedic-relief duo in Hollywood.

Another feat of the film is the way it is able to tell three separate narratives of different tones and still feel like one solid unit. If you're confused you'll understand when you see it, but Mendez has to go through three different worlds here to accomplish his task: one is in Washington D.C. with all the hammer down political who-ha, two is in the unpredictable and fun Hollywood scene, and three is in the life-and-death war zone in Iran. After knowing this you start to see the ambition of the film, and why Affleck should be commended for his efforts and awarded in their success. It's hard to notice how effortlessly the tone switches from an almost caper-style vibe in the Hollywood setting, to the intense, real, documentary feel in Iran. This is all thanks to a crisp screenplay that knows when not to overstay its welcome in certain scenes and sustains the over-looming idea that every second that passes, and every moment this fake film does not gain enough stability to achieve support from the government, the closer six Americans will be publicly executed leading to some not-so-peaceful diplomatic reformation.

An area I felt the film falls short in is in its tender moments, the parts where they try to probe at your heart for some tears and full character connections and relations. The theme of marriage and father-child relations is the most prominent emotional idea the film brings forth but it never quite emphasizes on it to the point of needing any sort of further resolution in the end; it attempts the jump but doesn't stick it. If Affleck could have accomplished this as well, the film would have impressed me even more, but as a result, doesn't blow me away. Regardless, Argo is a great achievement for Affleck and a film that should be seen. Although, It is not for everyone, so for those looking for some high-octane stuff, you may find much of it slow and boring, but those interested in good storytelling, solid performances, and attention to detail that will have you glued to your seat, you're in for a treat.

As a final note, I'd like to call to attention the name of the real CIA hero- Tony Mendez (Antonio Mendez). As you will also see if you watch the film and sit through the end credits, where they give you a wonderful juxtaposition of screenshots from the film to actual pictures of the real people and events, that Tony Mendez is a Mexican American. Hm, Ben Affleck- born in Berkeley, California with Irish, Scottish, and German ancestry. Pretty much everyone else in the film closely matches and resembles their real-life counterparts, but the lead actor who we see the most in the film does not. Just saying! Controversy anyone?

This historically inaccurate drama directed by Ben Affleck was adapted from the book The Master of Disguise by CIA operative Tony Mendez, and Joshuah Bearman's 2007 Wired article The Great Escape. Story is about Mendez who led the rescue of six U.S. diplomats from Tehran, Iran, during the 1979 Iran hostage crisis. Inaccuracies were never an obstacle for receiving seven nominations for the 85th Academy Awards and winning three (Best Film Editing, Best Adapted Screenplay, and Best Picture) - actually in most recent cases movies with such inaccuracies won lots of awards.

Affleck as Mendez did his job really well and Bryan Cranston, Alan Arkin, and John Goodman in supporting roles, were on the same level.  I mentioned the historical accuracy issue, and Argo has been criticized for minimizing the role that the Canadian embassy played in the rescue and for falsely claiming that the American refugees were turned away by the British and New Zealand embassies. In the film's narrative there was no adequate historical context for the actual events it portrays, and such errors of omission lead all of the Iranian characters in the film to have unbalanced depiction of an entire ethnic national group. Too much artistic freedom to change the events leaves bitter taste in my mouth. There were too many things which simply never happened: In the film, while pretending to scout for filming locations at a bazaar, the crew face suspicious glances, and are accosted by a few vendors, who suspect them of being American. In reality, this scouting trip never happened! In the film, the crew again encounters suspicion while purchasing plane tickets to Zurich [while at the Tehran check in waiting for confirmation of bookings for the group]; in reality Taylor's wife bought three sets of plane tickets from three different airlines ahead of time, without any issues. The film depicts a dramatic last-minute cancellation of the mission by the Carter administration and a bureaucratic crisis in which Mendez declares he will proceed with the mission. Carter delayed authorization by only 30 minutes, and that was before Mendez had left Europe for Iran! In the film, there is again a tense situation when the crew tries to board the plane, and their identities are nearly discovered. In reality, there was no confrontation with security officials at the departure gate! In the film, before the plane takes off, gun-toting Iranian guards try to stop the plane in a dramatic chase sequence; in reality, there was no runway chase at the airport. As Mark Lijek described it, "Fortunately for us, there were very few Revolutionary Guards about. It's why we turned up for a flight at 5.30 in the morning; even they weren't zealous enough to be there that early. The truth is the immigration officers barely looked at us and we were processed out in the regular way. We got on the flight to Zurich and then we were taken to the US ambassador's residence in Berne. It was that straightforward."

I still give the movie positive score - but it was just above average with too much imagination for a real event tag!  Enjoy the narration and don't think too much... if you do... you'll spoil the enjoyment!

Ben Affleck's latest film, Argo, tells the true story of a 1980 CIA operation to get six hostages out of Iran by disguising them as a film crew for a major motion picture of the same name. The film was completely fabricated with storyboards and posters just for the mission. It's an incredible story; so incredible that if it was not real, this film would feel completely preposterous.

   Argo is a story driven film, and that's not meant to be critical. What I mean by that is the major foundation of the film is this remarkable true story. Everything else is just exists to support it. The cinematography is solid, but not extraordinary. It does a good job giving the film a realistic, documentary feel without going over the top. Same thing goes for the editing. There are unique moments such as a scene when the main character is driving through the crowded city. There is shot of Iranians eating KFC and then, farther down the street, they cut to a man who's been hung from a construction crane. Juxtaposing these images together effectively shows the battle over the westernization of Iran in a visual way. Lastly, the acting is adequate. There are not any breakout performances or anything, but everyone is believable as the real life people under the circumstances.

   Munich, Lincoln (review coming soon), and even Hoosiers as well as many other films based on a historical event have an amazing gift of generating suspense even though the audience knows the ending. It's not a spoiler to say the hostages make it out of Iran. It's history. Honestly, Argo would not be nearly as good without suspense and Ben Affleck succeeds the way Spielberg and others have.

With more tension found within its run time than a highly strung back longbow, 'Argo' is a history lesson in a beautifully crafted art form - serving both as a way to teach its audience as well engross and entertain. Through being highly exciting, enjoyable and easily compelling 'Argo' as a film is able to outlay the fact with enough depth - to make it thorough - whilst not feeling to heavy - thus detracting audience attention from the content. From the outset 'Argo' takes hold of its audience, captivating them and keeping hold through its entirety, showcasing scenes that not only inform but placed between scenes of utter discomfort. It is this careful balance of scene types - coupled with excellent cinematography - that stands out most from the film come its close.
Stabilizing everything that the film strives to be, Ben Affleck (Director) manages to give across his filmic vision and through this determination to succeed with the film, 'Argo' feels complete in almost every element. Baring all about a human conflict, and the human side of politics, 'Argo' does not shy from the harshness of reality - with a side order of filmic history that may be unbeknownst to the majority of audience members. Much like last years 'The Artist', this film outlays a part of the industry that may not be common knowledge to the plenty - thus those who have interest in the subject matter will find enough to walk away having grasped something. 

A historical drama thriller, 'Argo' is adapted from the book by 'Master of Disguise' by CIA operative Tony Mendez. As such it is based entirely on fact - this true story nature of the film really helps deliver the intensity of the plot - and outlines the true story of Mendez - portrayed by Ben Affleck, who during the Iran Hostage Crisis (1979) managed to lead the rescue of six U.S diplomats hiding out in the streets of Tehran. By concocting a plan to stage a fake movie production, 'Argo', a science fiction epic, Mendez pretends to shoot his actors in the troubled country. By connections the CIA had, at the time, with Hollywood and the help of two working professionals, John Chambers (John Goodman) a make up artist and Lester Siegel (Alan Arkin) a working producer. 
By risking his life under the disguise of a Canadian filmmaker, with entering the American hating country, Mendez sets about to put his plan into action and help the 6 who are stranded in trying to leave the country. Under the codename 'Canadian Caper' this rescue attempt went down in both film history and that of CIA work. Therefore, the choice to produce this film really feels fitting when put into perspective of the collaborative efforts made by the people involved at the time. A homage to the past, and an outline to the manner in which cooperatively different industries can work to fix a greater matter, 'Argo' is an interesting watch, most definitely, and holds one of the most engrossing narratives of all time. 

Ben Affleck is a certified screenwriter, having gained recognition for many of his films, he is also an established actor fitting many different roles that have come into his career path. With an interest in directing and producing, his latest ventures have involved this side of the industry also. With 'Argo' the multi-talented  A-lister has been involved on the producing, directing and acting side of the film. To review his contribution to the film is to look into each of these. With regards to the producer role that he played, Affleck has crafted a film that is wonderfully made. A film that showcases the time it is set, whilst delivering a cast of relatively unknown - except perhaps the three main - actors into the films many roles. 
By choosing to produce this film to reflect real life, as a producer working to craft a film befitting its purpose, Affleck has succeeded in bringing a realism and tension to proceedings. As a director, Affleck has managed to bring his vision of events to the forefront of the film screen. His choice of locations and decision of framings used really manages to bring the narrative to life comfortably. By managing the pacing of the film, and by standing firm to his vision, Affleck is able to direct a film in such a way that characters become compelling to watch, and tension is so readily crafted. 
Finally as an actor, in the lead role none-the-less, Affleck manages to showcase his talent in this art form. Completely in the moment, his Mendez solidifies the threat and risk that he has in doing the job he has to do. Through being realistic in his performance, the empathy of the character is easily found, thus bringing about a connection that most lead characters struggle to hold. A one man army - with some help - 'Argo' is a film that completely testifies the talent held by Affleck in multiple filmic roles. 

Featuring a cast of actors that are found out of the Hollywood limelight, the film feels independent whilst maintaining levels more associated with the larger budget productions. Aside Affleck, the roles that work best within this film are those performed by Goodman and Arkin. With regards to Goodman, his John Chambers feels lighthearted - a great thing to find in such a tense film- and personifies the OSCAR winner in a manner unlike the other roles found. Argo is a solid, well-made thriller about the CIA's efforts to rescue six Americans who barely escaped being taken hostage when Iranian revolutionaries stormed the American Embassy in Tehran in 1979. We in Canada know of this as "The Canadian Caper" because the six were sheltered by Canadian Ambassador Ken Taylor and his wife. I was about 16 at the time and can remember the national pride felt and expressed when Canada took credit for returning those six Americans to their homeland. What nobody knew publicly then was that the CIA coordinated their escape by creating fake identities for the six as members of a fictional movie crew on a scouting trip to Iran. Although there are reports that some of the last-minute tension depicted in the movie never happened, it works as a movie and probably accurately conveys how nervous and scared the Americans were that they'd be found out before they could get out of the country. And you gotta love those '70s hairstyles and glasses!

The story of Argo might be hard to swallow if it weren't so wonderfully true.  A lot of movies claim to be based on fact but few ever come off with the feeling that they are anything more than Hollywood hot air.  Argo is different.  Based on fact, it tells a story that would collapse into phony cliché in other hands, but under the direction of Ben Affleck, the movie is a nearly perfect thriller about how, in 1979, during the takeover of the U.S. Embassy in Tehran, a group of Islamic terrorists were robbed of a handful of their potential victims.

The movie opens with the recreation of the takeover.  It says something of the craftsmanship of the film that despite the fact that we know how it ended, this scene develops a scary tension.  We see the revolutionaries breaking the chains of the gates and storming the embassy as inside the Embassy workers rush to shred and burn all of their important papers.  Fifty-two Americans are taken hostage, but six people walk out the back door.  Frantic to find shelter, they find that the only person who will give them shelter is the Canadian Ambassador who hides the group in his crawl space. 

Back home, the CIA is frantic.  Tossing out all manner of goofball ideas, they are at a loss on how to rescue their people until one of their specialists Tony Mendez (Ben Affleck) gets the goofiest idea of them all.  He will fly alone into Tehran, retrieve the hostages, and fly back out posing as a Canadian film crew who are there scouting locations for a bad science fiction movie called "Argo".  In the wake of the success of Star Wars, a rip-off seems perfectly logical, especially one that needs a desert location - hey if George Lucas can do it, why can't they?

The operation seems doomed from the start, but stranger things have happened.  Mendez hires an Oscar winning make-up man John Chambers (John Goodman) and a laconic producer named Lester Siegel (Alan Arkin) to help secure financing, make sure that the production is air tight and to make sure that the production makes the news - the Iranians need to be made to think that the movie is the real deal.

Meanwhile, Mendez flies into Tehran and lays out the plan to the trapped sextet who remind him that his crackpot scheme could mean their public execution.  Arriving in town he is reminded of the gravity of the situation when he spots a dead man hanging from a construction rig.  Time is of the essence, the movie repeatedly cuts back the Embassy where Iranian children and elderly carpet weavers are employed to stitch together shredded documents at the same time that the terrorists are becoming aware that six people who are on the Embassy ledgers are missing.

The final half hour of this movie is a masterwork of pure suspense.  Most filmmakers are satisfied with chases and violence for their effect, but Affleck trusts our intelligence.  He lets us in on a lot of information early on and establishes a well-plotted narrative so that we know what is happening all the way through.  When we get to the final half hour, we know who the players are and what is at stake.  We know the escape plot as the crew gets from one tense checkpoint to the next.  There are small details established in these scenes - a ringing telephone; a stalled bus; a bad computer connection; a locked door; a Polaroid photograph - that build the suspense out of logic, not cliché.  This film is so perfectly paced that you want to applaud it.

There are great supporting performances here, and that is key.  Victor Garber is perfect as Ken Taylor, the Canadian Ambassador.  As is Bryan Cranston as Tony's CIA contact who acts at a key moment when the mission looks like it will be recalled by the folks at the White House.  Also good is John Goodman as the make-up man John Chambers.  But the best praise goes to Alan Arkin in a wonderful peformance as the cynical, sleepy-eyed producer Lester Siegel who assures Mendez "If I'm making a fake movie, it's gonna be a fake hit."  Arkin, now 78, has always been a treasure, an actor who seems to occupy a movie with such ease that he almost seems to live there.

All of these elements come together in a movie that is wonderfully entertaining, suspenseful and at times very funny.  Affleck, with this film and his previous directing efforts on The Town and Gone Baby Gone has a sure hand as a director.  He clearly loves the craft and he respects us as viewers.  Not only that, but he puts himself in the starring role and resists the temptation to make it flashy.  He could reasonably have given himself a heroic posture here, but he lets us know that Mendez is only a key player, that so many people at home and abroad have a hand in this mission.

Argo could have gone wrong is so many ways, but there are sly in-jokes here about the way Hollywood works that you almost feel like rewarding it just for that.  There's a beautiful scene late in the film when the fake film crew show the airport security some storyboards for the science fiction film - they, of course, think the movie is real.  For a moment the young Iranians get so caught up in the magic of movies that they forget their jobs.  That this scene takes place at a moment teeming with suspense says something of the filmmaking and of the pure power of the movies.

The Academy loves a Hollywood comeback and in this case it was that of actor, and now reputable producer and director Ben Affleck in his resurgence as one of the industry's hottest and in-demand stars. After a number of box office disasters and Razzie wins and nominations, Affleck is able to demonstrate that although his position  as an actor may not be as one of the greatest of modern-day film, his presence behind (rather than in front) of the camera is something to be looked upon.

The winner of the Oscar for Best Picture truly encompasses what is and always has been the great American film - suspense, emotion and drama that is totally believable. Argo fits all of these categories as an almost-accurate depiction of the rescue mission of six American fugitives in the wake of the 1979 Iranian hostage crisis. This suspense-filled picture is a dramatization of the events following the nail-biting rescue mission of these six escapees with the support of the Canadian government and the CIA - led by intelligence operative Tony Mendez in his attempt to get the fugitives to pose with him as a Canadian film crew on location in Iran as a cover-up so they can safely return home.

The supportive performances of John Goodman as makeup artist John Chambers and Alan Arkin as acting legend Lester Siegel are used as comedic tools to instigate some kind of amusement in a picture that could have been - considering the historical context that this film's based upon - a truly depressing and sad story. Goodman and Arkin's performances are, interestingly, the only performances where we see some true and authentic acting come through. The roles of Mendez and the six hostages do not seem to be performances at all - let alone those done by professional actors. It's like watching a documentary intermitted with the reconstruction of a horrific event and that's why this picture worked. You seem to forget you're watching actors in a dramatized account of what happened in the fall of 1979.

I kind of wished Affleck would have stayed out of the picture completely and simply stuck to directing and producing - after all, the endless awards he won for this picture were for his behind the scenes work, not for his acting. Nonetheless, the film really isn't about acting at all or Affleck in that sense. It's really about retelling a sad and desperate time in world history that endless manipulated government reports cannot tell so well as a visual depiction such as this movie. 
George Clooney's print on the picture is also fiercely evident as one of the film's producers. The deep political atmosphere and context that "Argo" is based upon indicates that the film is more than just a drama; it's a piece of history that needs retelling and the almost-collapse of democracy.

This Oscar-winning film of 2012 was a pretty cool and accurate thrill ride through an important event of the Iranian revolution. 

PLOT:During the Iranian revolution in the 1970s, the people of Iran break into the U.S. embassy in Tehran and take 52 Americans hostage. However, six of the hostages are able to slip away and reside with the Canadian ambassador's house. No one has any idea what to do until Tony Mendez (Ben Affleck) comes up with the absurd idea of making a fake movie set in Iran, entitled Argo, to sneak beyond Iran's border and rescue the six hostages. With the help of director John Chambers (John Goodman) and Lester Siegel (Alan Arkin), he attempts to sell his idea of the fake sci-fi and make his way into Iran. It's a great plot executed very well. 

ACTING:The acting in here was pretty good. I don't think it was truly exceptional, but it was still really good. Ben Affleck played a pretty good part as the clever Tony Mendez. John Goodman and Alan Arkin were pretty outstanding as John Chambers and Lester Siegel, however. There were really no bad performances in the film, but aside from these guys, no one really stood out. 

SCORE:The score in here was pretty good. I didn't think it ultimately stood out, but it got the movie along well. 

OTHER CONTENT:This film was pretty cool. I like how it was based on a true story. Aside from the lead performances and good execution, this film seemed very accurate. From what I've learned about the Iranian revolution and the time period, this seemed very much accurate, along with the pictures showed at the end to clarify. However, I didn't like how it lagged in the middle and then suddenly picked up at the end. It makes it seem a little unbalanced. Do I think it deserved it's Best Picture award? Yes, I do. It's still a finely-done, accurate, thrilling for the most part, darkly-humored film that reminds me a lot of The King's Speech in structure. 

OVERALL,an awesome film with a great plot, pretty good acting, pretty good score, strong accuracy, dark humor, and thrills, but it felt uneven due to a lag in the middle.

Excellent movie with all the attributes I like in geopolitical spy thrillers. The fact that it's based on fact makes it even better. I'm as critical of American foreign policy as the next person but I have to say that the criticism of this movie being pro American propaganda is way off the mark. The movie accurately showed that the Shah's Iran was ripe for revolution and that revolution was inevitable if not warranted. It also showed accurately that the revolution turned ugly and that the religious fanaticism shown by the newly installed regime may have been populist but was hardly worthy of the popular support it at first received.

Aside from that the story was basically factual and poetic license was only used for entertainment, suspense and excitement. It certainly wasn't used to show America in any great light nor did it show Iran in an unfairly poor light.

In it's own right the tale was a good yarn and this film told it well. The acting was faultless, the direction spot on and the dark humour just about right.

Argo - Best Picture of 2012.  Really?  We have to live with that for the rest of our lives...how will I explain this to my grandchildren some day?  Don't get me wrong....Argo is not a terrible movie. But it does teeter dangerously on the border of "mediocre" and "sucks balls."  And that is only because of gifted performances by John Goodman and Alan Arkin.  Otherwise, it would drop right past "sucks balls" and into "destroy every copy."

Based on historical events, Argo attempts to recount the secret operation to rescue six Americans, which unfolded behind the scenes of the horrific Iran hostage crisis. As the Iranian revolution reached its chaotic peak in 1979, radical militants stormed the U.S. embassy in Tehran, taking 52 Americans hostage. Six "lucky" Americans manage to slip away and find refuge in the home of the Canadian ambassador.

The Argo team went to great lengths to get to the gnat's ass detail on the cheesy fashion, embarrassing hairstyles and Burt Reynolds-esque facial hair trends of the late 70's.  But after the initial embassy takeover, Argo veers off into a fictional "fantasy land" re-creation of the historical facts.  Worse yet, Argo completely ignores the REAL story of the 52 hostages who were held captive and tortured for 444 days.  Instead, they focus on a tiny sliver of success associated with one of the most humiliating chapters of US history.  Why, you ask?  Because Hollywood was involved in this great escape. Naming Argo "Best Picture" allowed the Academy to celebrate Hollywood's heroic involvement in this sidebar event.  High fives!!

Hollywood and dim witted movie goers everywhere seem to be enchanted with all things Affleck.  And for the life of me, I can't figure it out. The genesis seems to go back to the unimaginably over-rated Good Will Hunting. He can seemingly do no wrong - as an actor, screenwriter or director.  STOP!! Hold on a second - as Affleck may be involved in more unwatchable pieces of shit than any actor of his generation.  A small sampling includes Phantoms (1998), Armageddon (1998), 200 Cigarettes (1999), Reindeer Games (2000), Daredevil (2003), Gigli (2003), Surviving Christmas (2004), Smokin' Aces (2007) and the just released To The Wonder.  And let's not forget his directorial/writing/producing debut (no, this is not a joke), 1993's "I Killed My Lesbian Wife, Hung Her on a Meat Hook, and Now I Have a Three-Picture Deal at Disney."

There were dozens of 2012 films better than this middle-of-the-packer.  From Academy ignored gems like Moonrise Kingdom, Seven Psychopaths, Killing Them Softly, Bernie and Holy Motors - to mass consumption flicks like Skyfall, The Dark Knight Rises and The Avengers.  Even the animated Wreck it Ralph and Frankenweenie offered more bang for the buck.  Not that the Academy gave us a whole lot to choose from. Amour (getting old sucks),  Beasts of the Southern Wild (cute kid in a crappy movie), Life of Pi (bad book, worse film), Lincoln (superb acting in a lifeless movie), Silver Linings Playbook (mental illness can be cute, and funny!), Zero Dark Thirty (very good - even though I do not like pseudo documentaries) and Django Unchained (outstanding but overlooked).  Take out Zero Dark Thirty and Django Unchained, and Argo just may be "king of the shit heap."

Oh man. I have so much to say about this film. Let's start with its accolades: Argo won Best Picture, Best Adapted Screenplay and Best Editing at the Academy Awards, Best Picture Drama and Best Director at the Golden Globes, Outstanding Performance by a Cast in a Motion Picture at the SAG awards, and a couple of BAFTAs. All in all, the movie has done well.

Argo is about a hostage crisis in Iran in 1979, in which the US embassy was stormed because the US had taken Iran's previous dictator in, a person that the people of Iran wanted to be tried and hanged, and in protest to CIA operations in Iran. Six embassy employees escape out the back door, and find refuge in the Canadian ambassador's home, where they tensely wait for a way to get home. Tony Mendez (Affleck), a CIA operative, has an idea to make a fake movie, make the trapped employees pose as a film crew, and wheedle them out of Iran that way. An idea that may be crazy enough to work.   

The acting in this film was spot on. That SAG award was well deserved. Ben Affleck was great as the burdened Tony Mendez, Bryan Cranston killed it as Mendez' supervisor Jack O'Donnell, and John Goodman was an amazing supporting act as John Chambers, a Hollywood makeup artist who already previously worked for the CIA. But who stole the show in every single scene that he was in? Alan Arkin, who played Lester Siegel, the film producer. The guy was the perfect blend of witty, intelligent, and just downright cool. I cannot imagine the film without him. With all of the dramatic stuff happening in Iran, the film definitely needed a character to ease the tension, something that made the film very relatable and not too stiff. Kudos to Ben Affleck on that. Other than that, the roles of the Canadian Ambassador, and the six American employees were done very very well. I'm just too lazy to list everyone's names.

Now on to the film as a whole. The film was great, the dialogue was realistic, and Ben Affleck did a great job of keeping me on the edge of my seat without firing any guns. Many other reviewers have said this and I totally agree: that even if we know the outcome, it's still very exciting to watch. I loved how real news reports from 1979 were actually included and integrated into the film, it made everything feel all the more real.

My criticism? Well I'm not gonna bash too hard cause Ben Affleck is my hero. I understand that sometimes, dramatic license needs to be taken to make a film more watchable, but the whole making Tony Mendez the hero and giving the Canadians credit in the media and showing it as if they didn't earn it was garbage. Tony Mendez played a role in the actual crisis, but it was not as big as the Canadian ambassador, who in the film is merely regarded as a chauffeur. Ex-president Jimmy Carter and the Canadian Ambassador himself called Ben Affleck out on this, who changed the end, but it still didn't do Canadians much justice. It's also mentioned that the British and the New Zealanders turned the six employees away, when in fact both helped with getting them out of Iran. To me, logically, I feel as if these details could have easily been fixed in the film without screwing it up too much, but hey! Affleck had his reasons, I guess.

The next thing I wanted to talk about is the world's perception on Iran. Way to release a film bashing their country in the midst of a hostile nuke crisis with Iran and the States. The film definitely had too much 'look at all the killing and how crazy and terrorist-like these people are' and not enough 'these are the reasons for why they did what they did'. Just like, well, the US perception on all Muslims today. In the starting of the film, a reason for their outrage is summarized, but the violence and antics of the people in the film overshadows it by the end of the film, and I found myself unrightfully being a little pissed at the Iranians. I see a money making perception on this, as many people around the world are already pretty islamophobic and want films like Argo and Zero Dark Thirty to confirm their beliefs, but boy, did it still make me frustrated.

For ratings, I would like to give this film 4 stars because as I said, if little factors like making the film a little less pro-America and tweaking the historical facts so they don't piss anyone off happen, then it would be perfect. As a film on its own, it's great. As a film that's based on a real life event, more work could have been put into making sure the facts were straight.

Stunning visuals and brilliant characters create this spy thriller that keeps you on the edge of your seat - despite knowing the ending. Argo was surprisingly suspenseful, given its historical basis, and although it takes some creative liberties with the story it is fundamentally true. Alan Arkin and John Goodman demonstrate that they are the two people you want backing you if you ever plan to do anything this crazy, and the ensemble of American hostages are every bit what you'd expect. The plot gets a little unbelievable towards the end where soldiers drive jeeps out towards a taxing plane, but otherwise you'll be glued to the screen.

Even before it won the BAFTA and something called an 'Oscar' I was interested in watching this film. Ben Affleck had impressed me with 'The Town' and I was keen to see what else he had in his locker. I must admit he is certainly keeping the bar pretty high! Other than one, very debatable, comment about the fugitives being turned away by the British & New Zealand Embassies, it's a pretty fine film. Here's a very brief summary before I give you my thoughts.

After the Shah of Iran left in 1979 the country was in chaos. Fanatical religious factions took over who saw the USA as a great evil since they gave the, much hated, Shah a safe haven. This made life very difficult for the staff at the Embassy in Tehran; every day huge crowds gathered outside and chanted threats against the USA. Eventually they broke through the gates and took over the buildings but six of the staff escaped to the Canadian Ambassador's residence. As plans were drawn up to get them out, one man, Tony Mendez (Ben Affleck) comes up with something so audacious that it might just work! They were to pose as a film crew scouting locations in Iran, but to make it plausible; they'd need to make it look real. Enter John Chambers (John Goodman) and Lester Siegel (Alan Arkin); these guys set up all the marketing and press to make it look legitimate. So Mendez sets off to Tehran with his boss, Jack O'Donnell (Bryan Cranston), holding things together in Washington. Can he get the fugitives to agree to the scam, and what's more, can they pull it off and get out of Iran?... Guess I'd better leave you hanging there.

Beautifully made with all everything from the costumes to the technology accurate to a tee. I loved the way the film was intercut with archive news footage of the time; this really gave the audience a sense of the world at that juncture. All the performances were excellent with Ben Affleck taking centre stage, but I really enjoyed seeing Alan Arkin as a Hollywood producer; he stole it for me! There was real tension towards the end of the film; it slowly builds for quite a long time and I found that quite masterful. It's something that has been missing from many Hollywood films for a long time now but Affleck seems to have rediscovered the art. Because it's a film based in real events, there's little time for character development and I think it suffers slightly because of it. Other than that, it has some interesting songs on the soundtrack and it's well worth a look!

The most interesting part of Argo, to me, was the opening comic-book depiction of the events in Iranian history leading up to the Iranian Hostage Crisis in 1979.  Unfortunately, the rest of the film lacks the interesting stylistic vision of its opening moments.  Don't get me wrong; it is a well-made, competently acted, and engaging film that alternates between humor and suspense with some depth of political engagement underneath.  The plot is fascinating, particularly since it is based on a declassified CIA operation; however, the film devolves into a bifurcated narrative that never quite coheres in a truly meaningful way.  On the one hand, it wants to be a satire of Hollywood and its powers of illusion.  On the other hand, it wants to be a political thriller dealing with a controversial political event.  While it is entertaining on both fronts, it fails to bring the two together into something meaningful, and it really ends up downplaying the hostage crisis itself.  We never really get a sense of any Iranian characters.  Even interesting historical figures like Masoumeh Ebtekar (or "Mary" as the foreign press labeled her in a move of what Said would definitely call "Orientalism"), the spokesperson for the students who took over the U.S. embassy and still a prominent political figure in Iran.  The problem is that the film's fascinating opening section sets up the film to be a look a diplomatic nightmare that was--at least in part--caused by the United States' unwanted interventions into Iranian politics.  But the film leaves this behind as Affleck becomes a U.S. CIA superhero.  Too much of the film just feels way to slight for the intensely emotional and problematic event it depicts.  I would honestly love to see it redone with more of an objective, clinical approach to the events (like Bigelow adopts in Zero Dark Thirty or even a Michael Haneke type of disconnected presentation ) that presents them for our consideration without turning into a self-congratulatory tale about the United States will always win the day.

Ben Affleck is 3 for 3 as a director with this simply great film set during the Iran hostage crisis of the late 70s/ early 80s. Argo tells the story of 6 Americans who barely escaped the U.S. Embassy as it was being taken over by hostile Iranian citizens after the overthrow of the Shah. While the rest of the embassy staff become hostages, the 6 find refuge in the home of the Canadian Embassy's director. Knowing that the Iranians will soon figure out they are missing and hunt them down, CIA extraction specialist Tony Mendez (Ben Affleck) hatches a wild scheme to sneak them out disguised as a film crew scouting locations for a make believe science fiction epic called "Argo". Ben Affleck takes Chris Terrio's script and crafts a suspenseful, thrilling and extremely entertaining true life historical drama that manages to be a lot of fun despite the serious nature of the story. Affleck deftly weaves in some welcome humor to give us a bit of relief from the almost non-stop tension, in just the right amount to gives us a break and make us even more susceptible when he decides to turn the screws again. He gets great performances out of his top notch cast including, Bryan Cranston, John Goodman and a wonderful Alan Arkin as the Hollywood producer who helps him fake the production of the sci-fi flick Argo. He and his crew also do a great job of recreating the look and feel of that moment in time. This is a movie that lives up to every bit of the hype and deserves every award and nomination it received. And despite knowing how it all turns out, you still find yourself embroiled in some intense white knuckled suspense. Great flick!

Ben Affleck is 3 for 3 as a director and this might, depending on how you see it, his best film.  The problem I had with The Town, which was still an excellent movie, is that it peaks too early and goes on too long.  This film sees Ben at the top of his game.  This film is just excellent, there is a real sense of place.  The film just looks authentic.  Not that it's shot cinema verite style, just that the events of the film truly look like they're set in the late 70s.  That authenticity adds a lot to be honest.  The film, even with its inaccuracies, tells the incredible story of a courageous operation to rescue six Americans stuck in Iran during the hostage crisis.  and all this was with a very strange plan: using making a film in Iran as the cover to get these people out.  I think the most impressive thing about the entire film is just how far they actually went in trying to make the entire fake movie look like it's legit.  They set up a fake production company, had a very public script reading, they had posters, they had storyboards, they had newspaper articles.  It's just impressive to see how much they actually did to get their six diplomats out of a situation where, if they stayed any longer, they'd probably have been murdered.  Unlike The Town, the film does sort of build to an excellent climax with the last half hour of the film being outstanding.  There's just great tension and suspense to the entire operation, so kudos to Mr. Affleck for knowing how to build an atmosphere of tension.  The acting is, unsurprisingly, strong.  I mean with this cast, even if all else failed, you're guaranteed strong performances.  Even Ben Affleck, who I've never liked as an actor, turns in a strong performance.  He has a quiet confidence about him, it's clear that he knows what he's doing and he's fine not getting the credit he deserves just as long as he does his job.  I'm not gonna sit here and say that nobody else would've done this as good, or even better, than Affleck, but he does hold his end of the bargain on the acting side.  Really this is a top-to-bottom excellent film.  Did I think it was the best film of the year?  Probably not.  I can think of at least four other films I enjoyed more than this (Django Unchained, The Perks of being a Wallflower, Looper, Seven Psychopaths off the top of my head), but that doesn't make this any less great.  Even if the Canadian involvement was downplayed in the film, the film does tell a great story about an operation that, when hearing it at first, should've gone wrong but didn't.  Great film with a great cast and, surprisingly, a lot of funny moments as well.  Definitely recommended.

I have anxiously been waiting for my chance to review this movie.. but to review this movie, you have to actually see the movie first.  And it took me awhile to get the chance to see this, but I am happy to say I finally had a chance to see the 85th Academy Awards winner for 'Best Picture'.  So my biggest question before I watched the movie was: Do I believe it deservedly won this award?  I'll answer that last, but first my thoughts on the movie.  

Many of my friends had already seen this movie.  My parents too.  Every time I asked what they thought of it, almost all of them had one word come out eventually: intense.  And boy, is this movie intense!  Now let me make it clear:  the last 20-25 minutes are intense.  I mean INTENSE.  But other than that?  Eh.  Most of the movie consisted of talking.  And I'm sorry but if I'm going to listen to people talking for an hour and a half, I want Quentin Tarantino making this movie.  But Ben Affleck still does a very good job.  He brings in a great cast and a great script.  The movie is good.  There is no denying that. It's well shot, well acted, and well written.  John Goodman and Alan Arkin are great.  Ben Affleck is great.  I mean this is a very good movie.  But I wouldn't say this isn't one of my personal favorites.  It's not really a movie I will remember for years to come.  Do I think this movie should have been made?  Absolutely.  Ben Affleck gives the best effort he can in portraying a truly terrifying escape from hostel territory.  I enjoyed it, but I don't think it will be a movie I continuously watch throughout the years.

Now to the big question:  Do I believe this movie was right to win 'Best Picture'?  No.  But let me be clear, it's not MY personal pick.  Many people absolutely adored this movie.  I liked it, but I didn't love it.  I still believe 'Django' was my personal favorite of the year.  I still need to see 'Lincoln', 'Beasts of the Southern Wild', and 'Amour'.  But as of now, I don't believe this is the best film.  That aside, it absolutely deserves a nomination and it does have a strong argument for winning.  But in my opinion, still not the best film of 2012.

Overall, once again Ben Affleck proves that he continues to improve in his superb filmmaking abilities.  He is quickly becoming a classic of his generation.  I think I may have enjoyed 'The Town' more than 'Argo' but in terms of filmmaking as a whole, this is an improvement.  'Argo' is a very good, very intense movie.  I recommend everyone see it at least once.  Learn the harrowing story portrayed by a great director.

It did not take long for to know that Argo would be a great film. Directed and starring by Ben Affleck (Reindeer Games, Phantoms), Argo tells the true accounts of a declassified operation launched by CIA during the hostage crisis in Iran. The film opens up with a prelude into Iranian history, setting up the events of the film. It is 1979 and Shah or Iran flees the turbulent country. The people still unhappy and looking to even the score, seize the United States Embassy in Tehran taking a number of hostages. However, six workers have managed to escape and hide in house of a Canadian ambassador. Back in the US, the country is in cahoots with half of the Americans hoping and praying for the release of the hostages while the other half take vengeance on the mosques, Iranian flags, and people. The politicians are running around in circles while Jimmy Carter makes it clear they do not negotiate with terrorist. The CIA is pretty much bewildered, but find out six employees have escaped. They try and figure out a plan. This is when Tony Mendez comes in played by a shaggy Ben Affleck. He notices and objects to all the terrible plans proposed from bike riding out of Iran to farmers to Tehran while there is snow. Okay, you figure it out then Mr. Smart Pants. While on the phone with his son, Tony suddenly gets an idea while watching Battle for the Planet of the Apes. Why don't we make a fake movie and set it in Iran and have the hostages pose as our crew to get them out! His supervisor Jack O'Donnell and him then contact John Chambers (John Goodman). Chambers then gets producer Lester Siegel (Alan Arkin) to produce the fake film only on one condition: if I am gonna make a fake movie, it is going to be a fake hit!The film then transpires into a story of hope and determination. Tony tries to keep the mission going despite doubt and skepticism from superiors. Scripts are looked for possible production until a scripted titled Argo is chosen.  When asked what does Argo stands for, Siegel replies "Argo f**k yourself!" This fake film is will be in the spirit or more correctly, Star Wars rip off. The plans is "hi, we are Canadians looking to make a movie, so I came here to Iran for that exotic location." Get to Canadian ambassador and pick up the six Americans and have them play Canadians and then get to the airport and get out! Director Ben Affleck then takes us inside Iran. There is not a whole lot of personalities and identities just shots here and there along with turmoil going around the country. He meets up with the six which feel rather mixed at the idea. Tony does not have a lot of time because sooner or later the Iranian government is going to find out six embassy employees have escaped and will hunt them down. Director Affleck delivers a strong and effective film. It was intense watching this film as days go and every minute is crucial for the mission. Despite the turmoil, there are some delightful, feel good, and entertaining moments with Arkin stealing most of the laughs. Affleck also manages to deliver a darn good performance even though he also was in the director's chair. Goodman and the supporting cast are excellent in their parts. Now, like all films based on a true story, there are controversies. First, I am not sure about the history in the film; however, I do believe there are significant inaccuracies since this is history according to Hollywood. I also believe some scenes were added to jerk us around especially in one climatic scene. Argo does generalize some crucial points prior to the Iranian revolution, but was there any depth to it? I would imagine, but that is another film for another time. Anyways, it did not take too long for the film to click inside my head. I immediately sat back and watched the film. It is also no wonder it won Best Picture at the Academy Awards.

Argo, directed and starring Ben Affleck (The Town), is centred around the 1979 Iran hostage crisis and the efforts of one CIA agent, Tony Mendez (Ben Affleck). When the embassy in Iran gets raided, and seized by Islamic militants, six American diplomats managed to escape and find secret sanctuary with the Canadian ambassador. Months later, Mendez devises an audacious plan to get the six diplomats back to America, posing as a film crew looking for locations to shoot, along with the help of John Goodman (The Big Lebowski, Flight) and Alan Arkin (Little Miss Sunshine).

I feel as a whole Argo is the weakest Best Picture winner in many, many years. Although a technically very sound film, it suggests that the film business can solve the world's problems, including terrorism. For this reason I can see why those in Hollywood love this picture.

The film is well directed, I am under the opinion that Ben Affleck can direct anything that he is given, yet, for me, Affleck is better suited to Boston thrillers, he should stick to what he knows.  Furthermore, it's interesting that his portrayal of Tony Mendez is one that focuses on his trusting nature and smarts in terms of his mission, yet it fails to question Mendez' separation from his wife. It seems to me that that sub-story is just included so that it will form a nice ending when his wife takes him back.

One thing that surprised me about Argo is that the story expands in an oddly uncomplicated and non-shocking way. This creates a much more believable environment. If this film was a fiction, and not 'based on truth', there would be many more plot twists, or tense encounters that would dramatise and, in a sense, take the film too far into the realms of a Hollywood, fiction, action/thriller.

Ben Affleck's Argo, his third feature is a consummate piece of work. From the direction including the incorporation of archival footage in a delicate yet effective fashion really lent itself to the time period and the mayhem that was sweeping the nation and the world at the time. Several standout stars - Alan Arkin and John Goodman in particular really brought the work to new heights. However, there were several glaring issues with the script including an unnecessary and very cartoonish opening sequence that didn't let things off with a bang. Also, being that this film was supposed to be so focused on the hostages and their mission the hostages themselves barely got any lines of dialogue which seemed counterproductive to the action at stake. The most obvious and unfortunate issue with the whole film is the immense screen time that Ben Affleck took up himself. Many of those scenes were wasted with close ups of his eyes, smirking or brooding. All in all though, an impressively mounted and faithful production but nothing to really write home about.

Marvelous true story of the political thriller film. Congratulations to Ben Affleck for his Oscar (R) winner in this film's Best Picture at the first time, believe me it's his second Oscar (R) since he was awarded for his 1998's Best Original Screenplay in Good Will Hunting with Matt Damon. And it was disappointed Affleck wasn't entitled to be nominated for the Best Director Oscar (R). 
In the past five years, Affleck has mad the kind of comeback usually reserved for Rocky films. having been written off as "the least talented one" in the Affleck-Damon combo, the lantern-jawed actor has found a second life as a director with two acclaimed films. here he adds "producer" to the mix and sets about proving his "Bennifer" days are long behind him.
Based on the true story of a covert operation that was declassified in 1997, Argo sets about weaving together multiple elements with great efficiency: a handy history lesson on the conflict within Iran segues into armrest-gripping tension as 52 Americans are taken hostage from the US Embassy in 1979. Soon we're deep within the bowels of the CIA as troubled exfiltration specialist Tony Mendez (Affleck) relays "the best bad idea we've got" to the Powers That Be on how to save the six diplomats: enter Iran under the pretense of location scouting for a film, then smuggle out the quarry as crew members.
The film then successfully shifts tone as Mendez hits LA and Argo briefly becomes a biting (and hilarious) Hollywood satire. Alan Arkin steals every scene he's in as a wily producer who helps Mendez; John Goodman a delight as the make-up artist assisting in the charade. It's a short breather before the movie kicks back into "political thriller" mode as the director skillfully ratchets up the tension to unbearable levels.
Affleck again proves himself a talent behind the camera: Argo is well paced and several story strands are juggled skillfully. He's ably assisted by an A-grade cast: Bryan Cranston as a CIA higher-up, six relative unknowns as the diplomats and Goodman and Arkin in fine form. And proving he's better off directing himself, Affleck is solid as a CIA man-on-the-edge who everyone thinks is on a suicide mission. The sharp screenplay from Chris Terro is terrific, and despite a tying-up-the-loose-ends finale that reminds you you're still watching a Hollywood film, this is a triumph for all involved.

Introduction

This film is about a secret CIA operation in 1979 that saved 6 hostages that escaped from Iranian control and were in hiding.

Plot Summary

In this movie, a riot starts in Iran at a US embassy and they capture about 40 people. Six US ambassadors escaped and went into hiding at the Canadian embassy. The CIA found out they escaped and started to try and come up with ideas on how to get them out. They agreed on an idea to make a fake movie and say they were scouting locations to film in Iran. They came up with a fake script and storyboard and everything to make it as believable as possible. To get them out, they would say that the six of them were part of the production crew. The man that came up with the idea went to Iran and ended up getting them all out just barely. He later was presented with the highest award a civilian can receive for his brave actions.

Awards Won

This movie won the award for best picture in 2013. I think this is justified because when I was watching this, it seemed to have very good camera angles and picture.

Themes

I think the theme of this movie is stick together. I think this because the six of them that escaped stuck together and never left each other. Also, the US didn't forget about them and went and saved them.

Technical Elements

This film had very creative camera angles and very good picture. Which is probably why it won best picture. Also on very suspenseful moments, they would add very suspenseful music to it. This made the movie very engaging. Overall this film had very good technical elements.

Conclusion

This film was very good. I would highly recommend for people to watch this. One because it is a very engaging movie, and it also it is a true story so you can learn a lot from it. Overall this was a very great film and I can see why it won an award.

"Argo fuck yourself." After watching Argo post Oscar ceremony, I remain unconvinced that the film warranted the top prize at the award ceremony, as well as the best writing award. While the film itself was well made, it was never stellar or mind blowing. The story follows CIA agent Tony Mendez as he tries to get six Americans out of Iran by posing as a Hollywood filmmaker to get them out safely. Admittedly the finale was tense and thrilling but there was nothing bold or riveting about the film that gave it the privilege to be called the best picture of the year. Fun, simple and safe, Argo is not a bad piece of entertainment, but when the ever deviant line "based on a true story" comes up on screen, in this case it looses merits as Affleck took some creative liberties with the story, specifically the role of the Canadians in the film. While Affleck's Mendez's story is the focal point and was the part that was hushed by the government, the portrayal of the Canadian involvement in the "Canadian Caper" as it was called was cut very short, making the involvement almost none existent. Of course I was not around during this event and I did not know about the caper before Argo, but that's not to say what Hollywood says is true. Also, the film never reveals the fate of the other hostages left in the American Embassy, where the film opens up, leaving that piece of information  very open and unfinished. So if you want a fun, quick, easy spy thriller that doesn't get political, Argo is a fun distraction. If you wanted a deep political thriller with answers, well you may want to finance your own movie.

November 4th 1979, Iranians violently stormed the American Embassy and siezed hostages for 444 days. It was an intense and frightening era in modern history; this film chronicles the daring operation to rescue six of the hostages after they fled the besieged embassy.

I'm not at all familiar with the Iranian Hostage Crisis, so I have no idea how much of Argo is fiction and how much of it is fact (reading up on it, I see that the film is criticized for over-emphasizing the role of the CIA, and for presenting more peril than what really happened). Regardless, the film made the events feel very real. The film does it best to replicate the era, the settings, and the danger to immerse the viewers into the situation and make them feel the suspense. I certainly felt the suspense, as the characters ran up against all manner of political, diplomatic, and cultural barriers in a frantic race to escape a treacherous and unstable country. The film definitely kept my attention and had me at the edge of my seat.

The story is well-told, presenting its ideas and sequence of events on a manner that's both logical and sensical. Even though there is a lot of political intruige involved, the film never looses its audience with jargon or politics. It also looks and feels very realistic; despite some thrilling scenes, the events appear plausible and the various interactions between people and governments appear authentic. Characters have just enough depth and emotion to make audiences care for them, and once again, come off as seeming authentic.

Even the film itself feels authentic, featuring some rough and gritty-looking camera work and editing. The camera is steady and solid, as is the editing, but it looks like a film that could have been made in the 70s, due to the way it's composed and put together. Same goes for its production design, which goes to great lengths to replicate genuine-looking sets, props, and costumes. Acting is decent: Ben Affleck is surprisingly strong in his role, Bryan Cranston is a fun to watch as ever, and everybody else fulfills their parts admirably. Writing is great. Music isn't bad either.

Argo might just stand as a new favorite among political thriller movies; it's certainly one of the most real-looking and historically interesting films I've seen in the genre. Above all, it's intense enough to maintain interest.  Recommended!

Well, what can I say?  I had been wanting to catch this for a while but I was out of the country when it was playing near me, so I missed it.  But after it won the Oscar for Best Picture this year I made an effort to download it and watch it.  
First of all, out of all the other films nominated in the same catagory, I think Argo definitely deserved to win the award.  It's extremely tense in the exact places it needs to be, and since I made a point of not researching the real events the film is based on, I genuinely didn't know how things were going to "go down" (Although, of course, I assumed they'd succeed)  But Affleck has done such a good job that even though I subconsciously "knew" what was going to happen, I didn't know at the same time, if that makes any sense?  
It also uses humour very well.  I'm not saying it's a funny film by any means, but when comic relief is employed it does so extremely effectively.  
If I have any criticism (There isn't much I didn't like) I would have liked the film to delve a little deeper into Ben Affleck's strained relationship with his wife, and how he copes being so far away from his son.  It's briefly touched upon early in the film, but I feel if it was done a little more extensively, we as an audience would have felt even more tense and nervous during the Iran hostage extraction because there would have been a whole lot more for Ben Affleck to lose.  
So yes, a very tight and well done film that hits all it's marks very well.  It's still not my favourite film of 2012, but that doesn't take away from how good I think it is.

I don't usually go out of my way to see political thrillers. If I catch them on a lazy Sunday afternoon, I'll end up liking most of the ones I watch. "Argo" is one of those movies I would have passed up watching had it not been for one catch. The idea of the government using the making of a fake space / fantasy film to free hostages from Iran intrigued me. Once again, I'm very glad I listened to my instincts and took it in.

In 1979, six Americans are put in hiding by the Canadian Embassy when the U.S. Embassy is raided in Iran by militants. Everyone else in the building is taken hostage. The U.S. government decides to take the unconventional advice of CIA operative Tony Mendez (Ben Affleck) to get the six diplomats out of the country. He will enter Iran and smuggle them out as a group of filmmakers scouting for shooting locations for a fake science fiction / fantasy film entitled "Argo."

Ben Affleck continues to surprise me. He's always done his own thing in Hollywood. He'll do smaller films playing less conventional characters like "Dazed and Confused," "Mallrats," and "Chasing Amy." The next thing you know he's taking the lead in blockbusters and popcorn flicks such as "Armageddon," "Daredevil," "Pearl Harbor," and "The Sum of All Fears." Affleck's had his share of stinkers and received some unwanted attention in the tabloids as well. What actor hasn't?

One thing Affleck has done is prove he's a versatile talent in Tinseltown and isn't going away any time soon. He won an Oscar for his "Good Will Hunting" script and continues to collect awards for "Argo." The movie is nominated for an Oscar for "Best Picture" and it deserves the honor.

"Argo" appealed to me in so many ways. I was born in 1972 and was completely caught up in "Star Wars," "Star Trek," and "Planet of the Apes" fevers. A movie based in that time period about people making a fake sci-fi movie as a front to save hostages is captivating.

Add to that the fact that award-winning "Planet of the Apes" makeup artist John Chambers helped the government get the hostages out of Iran. I remember seeing the news broadcasts about the hostage situation as a boy, but I didn't understand what was going on at the time. The whole event is interesting to learn about.

"Argo" is an exciting political thriller which will have you white-knuckled and gripping the edge of your seat. Director Ben Affleck did a great job keeping up the suspense and pacing in the film. Even though you know how it's going to end, you are still nervous for the characters as you watch. That's just good filmmaking in my book.

There are times when real life offers a better story than any Hollywood writer could possibly come up with. This is the case with Argo. Argo tells the real life story of how a CIA operative named Tony Mendez (Ben Affleck), rescued 6 American embassy workers from Iran under the facade of a fake movie. 

After movies like Gone Baby Gone, The Town, and now Argo Ben Affleck has quietly become one of the better directors out there. The fact that he is not nominated for a best director Oscar this year is a serious snub. Argo is by far his best work and I will not be surprised when it is this year's best picture. 

Across the board the acting in this movie is top notch. They did a fantastic job in casting for this movie.  Ben Affleck is great as the lead and you can tell he poured himself into this picture. Jon Goodman and Alan Arkin are both very entertaining as his Hollywood support team. Lastly, Bryan Kranston is fantastic as Affleck's CIA boss. Kranston is a seriously underrated actor and needs to start getting some lead roles.

The key of putting together a good thriller is the right mix of suspense and enough character development that you are invested in the characters. Argo nails this on the head. You are rooting for these characters to succeed from the get go. There are a few parts of the movie that I did find slow and the family issues that Mendez deals with seem to be just tacked on for the sake of showing his life outside his job. These however, are very minor complaints on what is otherwise a fantastic movie. 
This year is going to be very interesting when it comes to best picture.  Argo, Zero Dark Thirty, or Lincoln could come away winning best picture and I would be okay with any of them. Argo is one of the shining moments in the history of the CIA and is a story worth knowing. If you haven't seen this movie yet, go out and see it!!!

Overall 9 out of 10:  adding to what is already one of the best years ever for spy movies.

Whenever I hear that a film is a "political thriller," I'm instantly turned off a little bit. Generally more political than thrilling, most films in the genre do very little to initiate the viewer into the political issue that serves as a backdrop, whether real or fictional. Without the requisite knowledge, I tend to get frustrated when I can tell by chase scenes and frantic music that shit just got real, but I have no idea what the political stakes are. Argo knocked it out of the park from the get-go with a nifty little storyboard introduction to the Iran hostage crisis that gave me a better understanding of the Iranian Revolution than did the entirety of the film Persepolis. With the political stakes properly explained within the first five minutes, Argo becomes cinematic stimulant. Ben Affleck the director was so effective that Ben Affleck the actor's sleepy-eyed calmness couldn't chill me out. And good grief that airport finale was some of the most thrilling cinema I've ever seen.

PS-Bryan Cranston should've been nominated for Supporting Actor over Alan Arkin.

This is probably the most hyped film of the group and it lead to it being this year's winner. Does it deserve the recognition? Does it hold up a candle to past winners? Well, one thing I can say is this film is masterfully done. Every member of this film's staff and crew should be acknowledged for this great work. This is probably one of the most fundamentally made films I've seen. It is just technically well-made! From the camera work to its editing, it is simply beautiful! But the plot is another story. It is based on real events set in the 70's with the American government trying to bring home hostages from Iran while pretending to be a film crew. That is a great concept! But as real and accurate as it feels, there just seems to be something missing. Sure, it generates enough suspense for you to be invested and the atmosphere feels so real. The cast are great especially Alan Arkin and John Goodman. The other cast did a great job but none of them particularly stood out. Overall, it is a very good movie. This is something that most people would enjoy except probably Iranians and Canadians.  It is the best decision of Ben Affleck's film career that I can't believe he's not nominated for Best Director! Generally, there are three themes that tend to be favored by award community and film critics, the winning themes are about humanity ("Schindler's List" {1993}, "The Shawshank Redemption {1994}, "Slumdog Millionaire" {2008}, etc.), patriotism ("Saving Private Ryan" {1998}, "Black Hawk Down" {2001}, "Lincoln" {2012}, etc.) and the world of cinema itself ("Cinema Paradiso" {1998}, "Hugo" {2011}, "The Artist" {2011}, etc.). Well, thiz movie has all three of them. Producer, Director and Actor Ben Affleck is smart enough to realize it and takes advantage of that. Ben Affleck is Tony Mendez, a CIA agent who is responsible for covert operation to extract six American embassy employees out of the rage of Iran revolutionary by pretending to be Canadian film crew.  It seems that Ben Affleck has done a tremendous job as the Director. He starts with an effective prologue to provide sufficient information and every time the scene heats up, particularly when the scene of American embassy is invaded, he cleverly adds relaxing piano instrumental music to cool things down and doesn't try to provoke audience into infuriated reactions. Thiz is his third feature films behind the camera after "Gone Baby Gone" (2007) and "The Town" (2010). For the acting, Ben Afflecks looks cool, calm and confident. John Goodman, Bryan Cranston and Victor Garber give brief but consistent performances and the last but definitely not least, Alan Arkin creates a powerful and believable emotion as fearless Hollywood Producer. I also have to put some credit to the Production Designer Sharon Seymour who successfully makes everything look like 1980s such as costume, hairstyle, glasses, car, furniture, television, telephone, everything! How they put attention to detail is undoubtedly amazing. Personally, for me, the power of thiz movie is in the last half hour. Thiz is a good example of what you can get when great script and great editing are perfectly combined. My heart nearly stopped while watching thiz final scene which takes place in Iran airport. They use almost all aspects to create tensions from ticket, telephone, soldier, bus, you name it and they have done it. When it's over, there will be some satisfying and gratifying feelings. In the closing scene, when the camera pans over the toys of Star Wars, Planet of the Apes and other sci-fi movies one by one. It simply wants to remind us that they are not only inspirational icons in our pop culture, but also they have ever saved lives. Great movie, great story, great moviemaker!

Ben's Argo and Lance's Medals

What do these have in common? 

Both generated great gobs of money, both represent a dramatic distortion of the truth, both take another significant chunk out of American credibility.

It is bad enough that a majority of America receives its education (17th or lower in world ranking) from movies, in Argo's case  "based on a declassified true story". When Ben claimed, in a recent interview, that the reason the Canadians integral role (90% Canada/ 10% USA - according to president Jimmy Carter and those actually involved) in freeing the hostages was not represented truthfully, he brushed it off quickly by commenting that "there was not enough time to fit it all in".

In other words, for Ben, making the Americans "centre of the universe" even under the guise of docudrama, trumps truth. The reality is that the small role the CIA did actually play, had the real potential of getting the hostages killed on their way out of Iran. Historically (pun intended) the CIA espionage folk put a wrong date on the passport stamp - which if not detected, and altered (again by a Canadian) would have meant instant detection, and potentially certain death on their way out of the airport - not to mention what would have happened to the Canadian embassy personnel.

Dramatic license must be extended to any historical account for time constraints or the inevitable lapse in research, however, when the focus is to distort and or pervert the truth, everyone involved suffers.

Ben in recent award shows, still attempts to use his youthful ignorance and surprised-face to pass off this travesty of history. I don't buy that, or the movie - nor should anyone interested in the truth. Historical accuracy can be every bit as dramatic and entertaining as BS with the added bonus of attracting a wider audience and staying on the charts for many more years.

No doubt, all those, who have or will receive monetary gain from this schlock will rally to its defense, somehow. There is no defense, however, for the damage inflicted on the historical record, those who buy into that distortion, or the Canadians, and the lives of six US hostages whose lives depended on real intervention by real people.

Thank goodness Mendez prefers the nickname Tony, seeing as how it makes him sound more American, because when I hear a name like the one on the person Affleck is portraying in this film, I'd sooner expect Luis Guzmán in the role, though, in all fairness, that might just be because Affleck is sporting Guzmán's trademark beard in this film.
